author: Nick Swedberg
title: Jury deciding fate of accused cop killer - Daily Southtown
text:
A Cook County jury is deliberating the fate of a felon accused of murdering a Metra police officer nine years ago in Harvey.
Prosecutors are hoping that circumstantial evidence and witness testimony will be enough to persuade jurors that Jemetric Nicholson killed Officer Thomas Cook in September 2006 near the 147th Street Metra station.
Nicholson, 28, is accused of shooting Cook, 43, a father of two, twice in the back of the head while the officer sat in his police car on a special detail investigating a rash of armed robberies near the station. He is the first Metra officer to be killed in the line of duty.
The jury began deliberating at 4 p.m. Cook's wife, Pam, and their two children, Jessica and Jimmy, were at the courthouse in Markham Tuesday for closing arguments.
Prosecutors argued that Nicholson and another man were planning to rob people on the night of Cook's death.
A key witness for the state was that other man, Jeremy Lloyd, who testified as part of a plea agreement that he was looking to commit armed robberies with Nicholson when they came upon Cook's marked car.
Lloyd said he watched as Nicholson raised a gun toward the open driver's side window of Cook's car and heard two shots as he turned away and fled.
There was no physical evidence linking Nicholson to the killing, but prosecutors told the jury that testimony and circumstantial evidence — linking Nicholson to a string of crimes leading up to Cook's slaying, including the attempted murder of a Harvey officer — is enough to convict.
The defense emphasized the lack of physical evidence against Nicholson and said the stories that supposed eyewitnesses gave over the years changed or that they flat-out lied.
Nicholson is serving consecutive sentences at Stateville Correctional Center on charges that include attempted murder. He won't be eligible for parole until 2145.
Officers filled Circuit Court Judge Frank Zelezinski's courtroom Tuesday morning for the trial that, as one witness from the Illinois State Police crime lab testified during the trial, involved "one of their own."
Nick Swedberg is a freelance reporter.
